Expect a few showers any time tomorrow, then local heavier showers and winds gusting to 45 mph very late afternoon and during the evening. By 2 a.m. Wednesday when the center is up over the White Mountains, rain will be over and winds dying down, so this is a fast-mover. Wind gusts may cause some scattered tree damage and a few power outages tomorrow evening.
A small storm surge of a foot or two is possible and may coincide with the mid-evening high tide. A major problem isn't expected, but the most susceptible low spots may see some overtopping of water.

© JUNETEENTH.com

Juneteenth is the oldest nationally celebrated commemoration of the ending of slavery in the United States. Dating back to 1865, it was on June 19th that the Union soldiers, led by Major General Gordon Granger, landed at Galveston, Texas with news that the war had ended and that the enslaved were now free. Note that this was two and a half years after President Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation - which had become official January 1, 1863. The Emancipation Proclamation had little impact on the Texans due to the minimal number of Union troops to enforce the new Executive Order. However, with the surrender of General Lee in April of 1865, and the arrival of General Granger’s regiment, the forces were finally strong enough to influence and overcome the resistance.

post_text:
Per R.I. Department of Commerce: If you are reopening your business in Phase 1, please note that you must complete and sign the following documents by Monday, May 18:

✅ COVID-19 Control Plan: Business owners are asked to fill out a simple plan outlining how they will prevent the spread of COVID-19 in their workplace. You *do not* need to submit that plan for approval. But keep it handy on your premises so you can consult it as you operate your business; you’ll also need to present it in the case of an inspection or an outbreak. https://www.reopeningri.com/resource_pdfs/COVID-19-Control_Plan_Fillable_Template-Final-5.13.20.pdf
